questions.question_text: What is the path followed by a projectile when it is thrown at an angle to the ground under gravity?
questions.hint: Projectiles under gravity do not follow a straight path.
questions.explanation: The summary states that the trajectory of projectile motion is always a parabolic curve in a vertical plane.
questions.solution: Option C is correct because projectile motion always results in a parabolic path.

questions.question_text: Which component of velocity remains constant during projectile motion?
questions.explanation: The summary mentions that horizontal velocity remains constant, while vertical velocity changes due to gravity.
questions.solution: Option C is correct because only the horizontal component of velocity stays the same.

questions.question_text: How is the initial velocity of a projectile resolved for calculations?

options.A: Into x and y components using trigonometric ratios
options.B: As a single vector along the trajectory

questions.hint: Resolution into perpendicular axes is preferred.
questions.explanation: The summary states that to analyze projectile motion, initial velocity must be resolved into x (V₀ cos θ) and y (V₀ sin θ) components.
questions.solution: Option A is correct because projectiles' initial velocities are always split into horizontal and vertical parts.

questions.question_text: What is the acceleration acting on a projectile near the Earth's surface?
questions.hint: Gravity determines acceleration in projectile motion.
questions.explanation: Acceleration in projectile motion is always –g ĵ, acting downward along the y-axis, as per the summary.
questions.solution: Option C is correct as acceleration is constantly vertically downward due to gravity.

questions.question_text: At the topmost point of a projectile's trajectory, which statement is true?

options.B: Vertical velocity is zero; horizontal velocity remains

questions.hint: Vertical motion stops momentarily at the peak.
questions.explanation: At maximum height, vertical velocity becomes zero, but the horizontal velocity (V cos θ) is unchanged.
questions.solution: Option B is correct as only the vertical velocity component is zero at the topmost point.

questions.question_text: How is the range of a projectile defined?

options.A: The highest vertical distance reached by the projectile
options.B: The horizontal distance from projection to landing point
options.C: The distance covered along the path
options.D: The sum of x and y components of displacement

questions.hint: Focus on the total horizontal distance.
questions.explanation: Range is described as the horizontal distance from the origin (point of projection) to where the projectile lands.
questions.solution: Option B is correct since range is always the total horizontal distance traveled.

questions.question_text: Why is projectile motion considered two-dimensional?

options.A: It involves motion only in the horizontal direction
options.B: It involves both horizontal and vertical motions simultaneously

questions.explanation: The summary emphasizes that projectile motion has simultaneous and independent horizontal (x-axis) and vertical (y-axis) components.
questions.solution: Option B is correct as projectile motion requires analyzing both x and y directions.

questions.question_text: If the acceleration due to gravity were not constant throughout the path, would standard projectile motion analysis apply?
questions.explanation: Standard analysis applies only when acceleration due to gravity is uniform near the Earth's surface.
questions.solution: Option B is correct since variable gravity invalidates the usual projectile motion formulas.
